column1: Millipedes are worm-like bugs called arthropods.
Millipedes are exceptionally well-endowed with defensive chemical secretions (toxins or poisons) that effectively deter most predators.
Contact with these secretions may cause allergic reactions in some people.

If the millipede toxin gets on the skin, symptoms may include: - Staining of the skin (turns brown) - Intense burning or itching of skin - Blisters If the millipede toxin gets in the eyes, symptoms may include: - Blindness (rare) - Inflammation of the membrane lining the eyelids (conjunctivitis) - Inflammation of the cornea (keratitis) Exposure to a large concentration of millipedes and their toxins may cause nausea and vomiting.
Tell the health care provider if any toxin got in the eyes.
